ARTICLE.TITLE: Hundreds line streets to farewell fallen police officer
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Police, paramedics, firefighters and members of the public lined the Adelaide streets in their hundreds to honour fallen police officer Joanne Shanahan.

Officers saluted the Detective Chief Superintendent as the hearse passed through the city's eastern suburbs.

Ms Shanahan's family watched on as complete strangers gathered along Greenhill Road and outside the Norwood Police Station to show their respect.

Hundreds lined the streets in Adelaide to farewell a fallen police officer. (9News)

Colleagues of the veteran officer carried her casket into a Magill chapel.

Ms Shanahan, 55, was killed in a horror crash at Urrbrae, two weeks ago.

The small but emotional service was streamed online for loved ones who couldn't attend due to COVID-19 restrictions.

Ms Shanahan's husband of 37 years, Peter reflected on his inspiration.

Detective Chief Superintendent Joanne Shanahan was killed in a horrific car crash. (9News)

"Jo would want you to walk away from this celebration of her life feeling empowered," he said.

"Jo would want you to walk away from this celebration of her life feeling resilient."

South Australia Police Commissioner Grant Stevens praised the long-serving officer as "one of a kind".

Ms Shanahan was praised as "one of a kind". (9News)

"We are lesser for her not being with us," he said.

He said Ms Shanahan's work in changing the way police dealt with domestic violence meant her legacy would live on.
